    • Introduction to oec

    Introduction to oec

    Mauricio Vargas S.

    2018-05-18

    user_guide.Rmd

    The OEC is the world’s leading visualization engine for international trade data. Using the oec R package is all about efficiency, without this package you could obtain the same data from the API at the expense of using additional time and effort for the same results.

    Package data

    Country codes

    If you don’t know a certain country code you can explore this data before using the functions.

    library(oec)

country_codes
#> # A tibble: 263 x 2
#>    country_code country            
#>    <chr>        <chr>              
#>  1 afg          Afghanistan        
#>  2 alb          Albania            
#>  3 dza          Algeria            
#>  4 asm          American Samoa     
#>  5 and          Andorra            
#>  6 ago          Angola             
#>  7 aia          Anguilla           
#>  8 ata          Antarctica         
#>  9 atg          Antigua and Barbuda
#> 10 xxa          Areas              
#> # ... with 253 more rows

    Product codes

    The OEC provides data classified using either HS92, HS96, HS02 and HS07 (Harmonized System) or SITC rev. 2 (Standard Internationsl Trade Classification).

    Each of these classifications consists in numeric codes and a detailed product name associated to each code.

    hs92
#> # A tibble: 6,282 x 5
#>    product_name                       id     group_name    group_id color 
#>    <chr>                              <chr>  <chr>         <chr>    <chr> 
#>  1 Horses                             0101   Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#>  2 Horses, live pure-bred breeding    010111 Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#>  3 Horses, live except pure-bred bre… 010119 Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#>  4 Asses, mules and hinnies, live     010120 Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#>  5 Bovine                             0102   Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#>  6 Bovine animals, live pure-bred br… 010210 Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#>  7 Bovine animals, live, except pure… 010290 Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#>  8 Pigs                               0103   Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#>  9 Swine, live pure-bred breeding     010310 Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#> 10 Swine, live except pure-bred bree… 010391 Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…

    Each product belongs to a group and the color column (given after groups) allows to use the same palettes at the official website.

    Package functions

    Getdata

    This function downloads data for a single year and needs (at least) a pairs of countries and a valid year according to the trade classification.

    The API returns data for different trade classifications: (i) SITC (1962-2016); (ii) HS92 (1992-2016); (iii) HS96 (1996-2016); (iv) HS02 (2002-2016); (v) HS07 (2007-2016).

    Correct input

    # What does Chile export to China?  
# year 2015 - SITC (4 characters)
getdata("chl", "chn", 2015)
#> Processing 2015 data. The classification is sitc.

# What does Chile export to China?  
# year 2015 - HS07 (4 and 6 characters)
getdata("chl", "chn", 2015, "hs07")
#> Processing 2015 data. The classification is hs07.

    The result is always an object titled origin_destination_year_classification.

    chl_chn_2015_sitc
#> # A tibble: 670 x 31
#>     year origin_id destination_id origin_name destination_name id   
#>    <dbl> <chr>     <chr>          <chr>       <chr>            <chr>
#>  1  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            5722 
#>  2  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            5838 
#>  3  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            6251 
#>  4  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            6282 
#>  5  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            6289 
#>  6  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            6352 
#>  7  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            6418 
#>  8  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            6572 
#>  9  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            6577 
#> 10  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            6631 
#> # ... with 660 more rows, and 25 more variables: id_len <int>,
#> #   product_name <chr>, group_id <chr>, group_name <chr>,
#> #   export_val <dbl>, export_val_growth_pct <dbl>,
#> #   export_val_growth_pct_5 <dbl>, export_val_growth_val <dbl>,
#> #   export_val_growth_val_5 <dbl>, export_rca <dbl>, import_val <dbl>,
#> #   import_val_growth_pct <dbl>, import_val_growth_pct_5 <dbl>,
#> #   import_val_growth_val <dbl>, import_val_growth_val_5 <dbl>,
#> #   import_rca <dbl>, trade_exchange_val <dbl>, pci <dbl>, pci_rank <dbl>,
#> #   pci_rank_delta <dbl>, top_exporter_code <chr>,
#> #   top_importer_code <chr>, top_importer <chr>, top_exporter <chr>,
#> #   color <chr>

chl_chn_2015_hs07
#> # A tibble: 4,730 x 31
#>     year origin_id destination_id origin_name destination_name id    
#>    <dbl> <chr>     <chr>          <chr>       <chr>            <chr> 
#>  1  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            0102  
#>  2  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            010210

#>  4  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            0106

#>  7  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            020120
#>  8  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            020130
#>  9  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            0202  
#> 10  2015 chl       chn            Chile       China            020220
#> # ... with 4,720 more rows, and 25 more variables: id_len <int>,
#> #   product_name <chr>, group_id <chr>, group_name <chr>,

#> #   export_val_growth_pct_5 <dbl>, export_val_growth_val <dbl>,
#> #   export_val_growth_val_5 <dbl>, export_rca <dbl>, import_val <dbl>,
#> #   import_val_growth_pct <dbl>, import_val_growth_val <dbl>,
#> #   import_val_growth_pct_5 <dbl>, import_val_growth_val_5 <dbl>,
#> #   import_rca <dbl>, trade_exchange_val <dbl>, pci <dbl>, pci_rank <dbl>,
#> #   pci_rank_delta <dbl>, top_exporter_code <chr>,
#> #   top_importer_code <chr>, top_importer <chr>, top_exporter <chr>,
#> #   color <chr>

    Incorrect input

    HS02 is available from 2002 and ongoing:

    # What does Chile export to China?  
# year 2000 - HS07 (4 and 6 characters)
getdata("chl", "chn", 2000, "hs02")

    Special cases

    This won’t return a valid output because there is no available data:

    # What does Andorra export to France?  
# year 2015 - SITC (4 characters)
getdata("and", "fra", 2015)

    The problem here is not the user input because Andorra used a different classification in 2015:

    # What does Andorra export to France?  
# year 2015 - HS07 (4 and 6 characters)
getdata("and", "fra", 2015, "hs07")

    Getdata batch

    Getdata

    This function downloads data for a sequence of years and needs (at least) a pairs of countries and a valid initial and final year according to the trade classification.

    The API returns data for different trade classifications: (i) SITC (1962-2016); (ii) HS92 (1992-2016); (iii) HS96 (1996-2016); (iv) HS02 (2002-2016); (v) HS07 (2007-2016).

    # What does Chile export to China?  
# years 2010 to 2015 - SITC (4 characters)
getdata_batch("chl", "chn", 2010, 2015)

# What does Chile export to China?  
# years 2010 to 2015 - HS07 (4 and 6 characters)
getdata_batch("chl", "chn", 2010, 2015, "hs07")
 
# What does Chile export to China?  
# years 2010 and 2012 - HS07 (4 and 6 characters)
getdata_batch("chl", "chn", 2010, 2012, "hs07", 2)

# What does Chile export to China?  
# years 2000, 2005 and 2010 - HS92 (4 and 6 characters)
getdata_batch("chl", "chn", 2000, 2010, "hs07", 5)
